content:
Now that we have completed our primary goal, the next major goal is to finish the writing of the draft paper. (One can of course still pursue additional spinoff projects, as we have already been doing for instance with the finite magmas spinoff, or make technical improvements to the codebase; but in my mind the "official" part of the project will wrap up once the paper is written, submitted, revised, accepted and published.)

We already have several issues claimed equational#873 equational#922 equational#926 equational#956 to contribute chapters or subsections to the draft that are still outstanding. Perhaps this thread can be used for the contributors who had claimed these sections to report on their status.

One of the writing issues, equational#924 (writing a section reporting on the finite magma implication spinoff project), remains unclaimed (a stub exists in the draft at Section 8). A volunteer to claim this section also would be greatly appreciated!

I plan to go through the draft later today to update it and identify any further issues to formally make (based on several boldface comments currently in the draft). A lot of it is in decent shape though, so I think once we have the contributed chapters we can move into the proofreading and polishing stage. (But if anyone has any suggestions for the global structure of the paper, this thread would be a good place to discuss them.)

If any contributors wish to register themselves as a participant or co-author of the project but has not yet made a contributor PR listing your contributions, this would be a good time to do so. Contributors can also update their contact and contribution details in Appendix B of the paper.

An obvious journal for this paper, by the way, would be the newly formed Annals of Formalized Mathematics, but this would also be a good time to discuss any other possible options.
I guess for most junior people in academia, an established venue would help more than a new one. But I don’t know much about math journals so I can’t really suggest alternatives

I've gone through the paper and done some cleanup. For instance, I've removed the "statistics" section as we don't really have much to report here (but instead sprinkled some more stats about the implication graph elsewhere in the paper), and also shortened the "Author contributions" section since we are using the contributions.md file as our main source here. (But we should include contact information and affiliation in the main paper still; if you are listed as an author but have not entered in this information, feel free to submit a PR or else DM me with the required details.)

The most significant content I added was in the "conclusions" section (Section 13), where I proposed some lessons to draw from the project, and some future directions. This is very much a tentative draft for this section, and I very much welcome more input to weigh in on what lessons to draw from this project. There may be things that I omitted, or misrepresented, or perhaps are not worth saying, so any feedback would be encouraged here.

I also wrote something for Section 3 (formal foundations), though I was a little unsure about some of the backend stuff (e.g., how we ended up implementing laws vs equations), so some scrutiny and corrections here would also be welcome.

One section that is still completely missing is Section 12 (data management), which is something we really haven't talked about. Presumably the Github repository will be our primary data repository going forward. The actual data of our project, particularly the implication graph, can be accessed from Equation Explorer, though I don't think we quite have a way of converting an arbitrary edge in the graph to an actual Lean theorem yet. Is there anything we could do to make the data we have more accessible that doesn't require an enormous amount of additional effort?

The actual data of our project, particularly the implication graph, can be accessed from Equation Explorer, though I don't think we quite have a way of converting an arbitrary edge in the graph to an actual Lean theorem yet.

That sounds like a relatively easy task (a lot easier than constructing the full implication graph in lean)
the easiest implementation I can think of is to just have explain_implication.py produce json output and then have a lean tactic use that to figure out which theorems to string together

oh this is fun, I proved false using explain_implication.py

$ scripts/explain_implication.py Equation2 Equation2
Found contradiction!

Equation2 => Equation2  (tautology)
Equation374794  has a model that does not satisfy  Equation2
    InfModel.Equation374794_not_implies_Equation2  in  InfModel.lean
Equation374794 => Equation2
    InfModel.Finite.Equation374794_implies_Equation2  in  InfModel.lean
Oh, is there some bug in confusing the finite implications with the infinite ones?

Re data management: last year, I believe somebody mentioned a specific science data repository which could host a long-term archive copy of the repo as it is on the date of acceptance.

At the moment my Zulip-fu is not strong enough to find it, though. Does anybody remember who/what this was?
Zenodo, probably? It's a repository with DOIs (so, good long term archival) that's particularly built to preserve code or datasets.
Indeed, and MathBases, mentioned here
Thanks @Alex Meiburg !
We are listed on MathBases at https://mathbases.org/d/equational-theories but it is just a small amount of metadata, the repository itself is not hosted there.
Submitting a static copy of the repo to Zenodo upon acceptance of the paper makes sense to me.

I also wrote something for Section 3 (formal foundations), though I was a little unsure about some of the backend stuff (e.g., how we ended up implementing laws vs equations), so some scrutiny and corrections here would also be welcome.

Happy to give that one a shot (and send a PR)!
Great! I've opened equational#1178 to officially make this an issue for you to claim. EDIT: Oh, I see you already submitted the PR, so I'll close this issue as completed.

I have a branch with 80% of https://github.com/teorth/equational_theories/issues/956 done which I worked on last year :sweat_smile: -- I don't think there's much left to do except hunting down some refs, so I'll make time over the next while.

I am drafting the section on how we managed this project. I will be making commits in small chunks every now and then. There are some TODOs in the middle, mostly about looking for citations or notes to double check a point.

  1. If you have any suggestions, especially about the TODOs, feel free to comment on the PR, even as I draft it.
  2. Comments about the broader thrust of the content would be more helpful once the draft is complete, since I am likely to make non trivial changes to the content anyway.
The relevant PR is here: https://github.com/teorth/equational_theories/pull/1038
Could we shorten the paper title a bit? It seems rather long.
The current subtitle sounds like a sentence that belongs in the abstract.

I think it's a matter of what you find to be the most exciting aspect of the project. In my opinion, the actual material mathematical results (while neat and interesting!) are not likely to be of particularly broad or deep interest; the meta-level fact that the project could be distributed and verified as it went along (and the distribution relied on verification, in the sense that it meant we didn't have to 'trust' each other) will maybe be the most intriguing part of the project. Hence why the paper also goes into pretty substantial detail about the discovery process, which is typically glossed over in a math paper.
I get what you mean, but I think the subtitle could at least be shortened.

We don't need to single out lean or github in the subtitle at the very least. Github, while immensely valuable, is definitely not ireplaceable in the project. We could have accomplished everything just the same with bitbucket, trello, gitlab etc.
Maybe "The Equational Theories Project : Mathematical Research at Scale"
Or "The Equational Theories Project : Scaling Mathematical Collaboration"
These work for me. Any other proposals? I can set up a poll.
Maybe something that feels slightly more "complete" like The Equational Theories Project: Advancing Collaborative Mathematical Research at Scale ?
I don’t think we need to make it so qualified. A slightly shorter title that gets the gist across is better

/poll What is your preferred title for the paper?
The Equational Theories Project: Using Lean and GitHub to complete an implication graph in universal algebra
The Equational Theories Project: Mathematical Research at Scale
The Equational Theories Project: Scaling Mathematical Collaboration
The Equational Theories Project: Advancing Collaborative Mathematical Research at Scale
Other
It's far from a consensus, but I have gone ahead and implemented the plurality title choice of "The Equational Theories Project: Advancing Collaborative Mathematical Research at Scale"

Terence Tao ha dicho:

We already have several issues claimed equational#873 equational#922 equational#926 equational#956 to contribute chapters or subsections to the draft that are still outstanding. Perhaps this thread can be used for the contributors who had claimed these sections to report on their status.

As contributor to equational#922, I must say I have yet to start writing :sweat_smile: I have some commitments to students right now that I must fulfill first, but once I start writing, it shouldn't take too long.
Do we have the minted latex package already in the source? I would like to use it to insert lean4 snippets
I don't think so, but feel free to add it if it is not there

Do we want to submit the paper to CPP 2026?
https://popl26.sigplan.org/home/CPP-2026
The deadline is 2025-09-05 for abstracts and 2025-09-12 for papers.

Unfortunately, they allow only 12 pages (appendices are possible tho).
Also, I don't know whether it is feasible for our paper to undergo a double-blind reviewing process.
It's not your problem as an author to worry about a double-blind reviewing process, so this shouldn't be a consideration.
However my impression is that cutting it down to 12 pages might involve some big (and in fact unreasonable) sacrifices.

In most computer science conferences, double blindedness means that you shouldn’t go out of the way to advertise the authors to the reviewers. I don’t know if the PL community has moved on to a stronger standard
But basically putting stuff on arxiv is fine
If the reviewers find out without intent that is also unavoidable and therefore fine

Also I know this is specific to some communities but huge appendices are not uncommon in some CS conferences these days. Entire papers exist in appendices and the “main” paper is an extended abstract and overview of results. Again, I am not sure if this flies at CPP.

Alternatively, we could publish a conference and a journal version. This will count as one publication unit within CS. I don’t know how this changes in math.

One point to note is that the ACmart class with 10pt font is quite dense compared to what we are using right now.

Given the slow pace of writing the primary paper, I am not optimistic about the ability to produce a second paper in a reasonable timeframe, and I am not sure what additional content it could have that would not already be suitable for the primary paper (or for supplemental material such as the blueprint). I could imagine the ETP data being a component of some future research project that could go into a venue like this, but this might be accomplished by some other group of collaborators than the ones for the primary objective of the project.
The basic reason for slow progress is that I think for a lot of us, academic and work life caught up
We were able to give a lot of time to the project in the initial months, but the resultant backlog eventually caught up with many of us

Are we close enough that it's worth doing some copyediting? There are some minor typos (4694 vs. 4964) and inconsistent use of hyphenation, some cases where diacritics are lost from names, etc. We'll have to do it again later anyhow, but some of these are going to need to be fixed regardless.

I have to admit it was an AI that spotted the 4964 typo in the third sentence of the paper.. :sweat_smile:
Sure, feel free to submit PRs for these sorts of corrections.

I'm wondering about some chapters of the blueprint. There are some non-trivial results hidden there, at least some about specific laws such as weak central groupoids, or magma cohomology, or the spectrum (not quite yet in the blueprint). If the blueprint is submitted as supplemental material to the main publication, these more detailed results would no longer be publishable since they would already appear as part of a publication, but at the same time they would be pretty hard for people to find and reference.
I should get around to putting a CITATION.cff for the equational theories github repository, so that one can at least reference through that
OK, we now have a CITATION.cff : equational#1265
To all authors : Please check for underflow and overflow warnings. Please eliminate them in your PRs
Are you planning to fix the errors that you find in other sections in your own PR? I can go through the entire paper to address these, but I want to avoid merge conflicts.
I don’t think these will be merge conflicts since they are in separate files
Right, the question is whether you wish to fix the errors in these other files, or if you would like me to do so. If we both do so then there could be a merge conflict.
I prefer these fixes to be a separate PR
Since they touch different files, there is no worry of merge conflicts
So I don’t mind it if you make a pass through the paper. If any merge conflict does arise, I should be able to handle it.
OK, then I will go through the paper now.

What's the best procedure to comment on random bits of the paper that might need some edits, but will need someone else to chime in?

For example:

We also define the order of a word $w \in \Magma_X$ to be the number of occurrences of $\op$ in the word, thus letters in $X$ are of order $0$, and the order of $w_1 \op w_2$ is the sum of the orders of $w_1, w_2$.

Doesn't that need to be 1+order(w_1)+order(w_2)?

And

In fact, since these equations preserve the space of homogeneous polynomials of a fixed degree, one can use linear algebra to locate an example that is a homogeneous polynomial; one explicit choice is f(x,y)=y5+xy4+x2y3+3x3y2+3x4y1f(x,y) = y^5 +xy^4 + x^2y^3 +3x^3 y^2 + 3x^4 y_1f(x,y)=y5+xy4+x2y3+3x3y2+3x4y1​.

where y_1 must be a typo, etc.
This is as good a place as any (the Github issues page would also work). I've fixed the two typos you mentioned.
Just pushed a conceptual overview of the project contribution process with a couple of figures. I didn't rehash all of CONTRIBUTING.md

what remains is describing the importance of maintenance and scalability issues, and shortening the description of the trust issues with ITPs (adding a reference to Mario's explanation from the external checkers book)

/poll Where do we want to submit the paper? [This is not a referendum. I'm just curious about what people think.]
Annals of Formalized Mathematics
Journal of Automated Reasoning
A different journal?
A conference?
I put down a vote for AoFM as it is a newer journal and I felt this would be a way to support it, but if there is a majority preference for JoAR instead I'm fine with that one as well.

More misc comments!

Possible typo?

One such example is the refutation $\Eq{1485} \vdash \Eq{151}$, which we discuss further in \Cref{twisting-sec} below.

E1485⊬E151 , no?

Maybe typo, maybe confusion on my part: in the explanation of the greedy method, we write:

• Case 4: x, y, x ⋄′ y, y ⋄′ (x ⋄′ y) != c: this case is covered by Rule 3 for ⋄.

I'm not sure how rule 3 applies here. I would have thought something more like

“Case 4: x, y, x ⋄' y, y ⋄' (x ⋄' y) != c. In this case ⋄'=⋄ on all pairs, so the claim reduces to Rule 1 for ⋄, which holds by the induction hypothesis.”

and the appeal is to rule 1, not 3.

When we introduce the twisting semigroup in 5.4, with example 5.11, does that equation really follow from E1485 with TU=UT & T^2=E^3? How do we kill the TU on the LHS after x->TUx? We haven't assumed TU=1 yet, and we're working with endomorphisms, not auto. Could probably use some more explanation.
Thanks! I have fixed the typos. One should indeed assume that TU=UT=1, not just TU=UT, here.
Could someone review example 5.2, the counterexample to E1286->E3? I'm having two separate arithmetic challenges with it (the variety calculation itself and the second p,a,b example.)
Looks like there was a spurious "+a" term in the first equation defining the variety; I've fixed that now.

Good, that matches my calc too. For the second issue, I don't see how p,a,b=(7,6,2) works here. 6+2=8=1 mod 7, so a+b=1, and won't E3 be satisfied? I think that combination satisfies E1286, but won't work as a witness.
Ah, you're right; the p=7 model is the smallest nontrivial model for 1286 but it is indeed idempotent (obeys E3). This was not properly reported in the commentary for 1286 so I am changing that also.

On prop 5.16, E1659 =/> E4315, I'm confused.

A minor point is that I think in (1, 0) != ((0, 0) ⋄′ (1, 0)) ⋄′ (((1, 0) ⋄′ (1, 0)) ⋄ (1, t)) we'll need the last ⋄ to be ⋄' as well.

A more major one is that I'm not sure the proof works as written, in that the override seems to violate 1659. Unfortunately this requires me to trust my arithmetic, a fool's game. :wink:

G has carrier Z/2Z and M has carrier Z. If we set "(0, 0) ⋄′ (1, t) = (0, 0) for all t ∈ Z" as the paper says, then x=(0,0), y=(1,-1), and z=(1,0) gives LHS=(0,0) and RHS of (1,0), breaking E1659, so it can't witness the refutation.

It looks to me like both this model and the parity model from the blueprint only work for N, not Z, and we should adjust the text accordingly, both the carrier and the examples.

If so, the wording in the blueprint that "At this point one might as well truncate the model to N" seems a little misleading, because it's not like things were working over Z and we dropped down to N for simplicity. I seem to see lots of E1659 violations in Z.

As always, caveat lector!
Thanks, I have reworded the text in the paper and blueprint accordingly.

In the proof of lemma 6.9, E854->E378, I think we set y=S^2 x when we meant to set z=S^2 x in this line:

$$x = x \op f(x,S^2 x,x) = x \op S(x \op S^2 x) = x \op S(x \op f(x,x,x)) = x \op Sx.$$

Otherwise I can't see how the f()->S() step goes, but if it's meant to be y:=x, z:=S^2 x, we get
f(x,x,S^2 x) = ((x∗S^2 x)∗(x∗S^2 x)) = S(x *S^2 x) as needed.
Fixed, thanks!

So I'm trying to follow the "canonization" section. A lot of the rewriting-related stuff still feels like magic to me, so maybe I'm just missing the sleight-of-hand. :wink:

My current problem is that our definition 6.6 of canonizer seems so weak! All we have is that C is computable and that w_1 ~=_E w_2 => C(w_1) = C(w_2). So it's kind of a class labeller. Most other references I've found involve soundness, idempotence, and compositional assumptions. It seems like a trivial canonizer C(w)=x would match our definition, and if that's true we're clearly limited in what we can conclude.

Note that we can then take the image of C and endow it with a magma structure simply by
taking w1 ⋄ w2 := C(w1 ⋄M_X w2 ). This magma refutes E ′ if C sends the left-hand-side and the right-hand-side of E′ to distinct elements of MX .

At this point all C has is computability and class invariance. How do we know this image actually models E?
@Cody Roux I think you wrote this part of the paper, would you be able to weigh in on this?

@Terence Tao @Douglas McNeil Sure! I was somewhat mystified as well, so perhaps, barring mistakes on my part, we can build a better explanation for the text.

First, note that in

w1≃Ew2⇒C(w1)=C(w2)w_1\simeq_E w_2\Rightarrow C(w_1) = C(w_2)w1​≃E​w2​⇒C(w1​)=C(w2​)

I mean "for any provable equation from E", rather than just

E={(w1,w2)}E = \{(w_1, w_2)\}E={(w1​,w2​)}

Generally, you'd like at least one additional property from your canonizer, namely

C(w)≃EwC(w)\simeq_E wC(w)≃E​w

which gives you

w1≃Ew2⇔C(w1)=C(w2)w_1 \simeq_E w_2 \Leftrightarrow C(w_1) = C(w_2)w1​≃E​w2​⇔C(w1​)=C(w2​)

as expected. But actually this is stronger than what we want, which is just to refute implications! And indeed the Lean proofs do not prove this extra property, at least directly.

I'm not sure I found a very standard definition of a canonizer, though I guess a case can be made that it includes this second condition, in which case we need to find another term, maybe "weak canonizer", though I used that elsewhere for something else.

At this point all C has is computability and class invariance. How do we know this image actually models E?

This is the bit I'm actually not sure about. Actually, no, I'm sure this is wrong.

In the code they actually have the additional idempotence hypothesis, but that's also not enough. They just prove each special case, but there the canonizer is defined as in definition 6.7, so everything works out: C_R is idempotent and a morphism to the magma defined as above. The trick is that R actually satisfies some pretty strong conditions (the subterm and non-overlap stuff). This makes C_R idempotent but also respect substitutions on the image.

I should note that we don't actually need this, since if C sends E- equal words to distinct terms, it's definitely a matching invariant (in the sense of 6.2) like mentioned in the previous sentence, and so we don't actually need this to be a magma satisfying E in the rest of the paragraph.

Still I'm annoyed at the mistake, and the lean code does prove that each instance is a model for the given magmas. Maybe I can explain why it holds in this case.

(As an aside, the matching invariant mentioned in Proposition 6.1 is the universal invariant).

Second sidenote: I notice that in the following paragraph they use

x∼Eyx \sim_E yx∼E​y

instead of

x≃Eyx \simeq_E yx≃E​y

Should I change my notation?

Let's see if I'm following..

So we use the class invariant C just to show non-derivability, without insisting that im C models E. We're only appealing to Birkhoff completeness (magic! :magic_wand:)

I guess the text as written never actually claims it's an explicit refuting model for E/E', but "this magma refutes" does make it sound like that.. even though we really just mean "We’ll use a computable, EEE-invariant CCC purely as a proof-theoretic refutation: if C(LHSE′)≠C(RHSE′)C(\text{LHS}_{E'})\neq C(\text{RHS}_{E'})C(LHSE′​)=C(RHSE′​), then E⊬E′E\nvdash E'E⊬E′ (by Birkhoff completeness)" or something.

To answer my earlier concern, the trivial mapping to a constant element is indeed a valid "canonizer" by 6.6, it just doesn't have any separating power as a refutation witness, because by construction there's never going to be anything different on the two sides. So it's not a problem that it's valid, nobody ever promised every canonizer would have much proving power! I guess that makes sense too.

By way of contrast, for a explicit countermodel/model-theoretical refutation we'd need a compositional C to ensure im C models E, and 6.6 doesn't suffice. I'm not sure whether even 6.7 does.. I've gone back and forth on whether I think 6.7 implies idempotency on its own. Currently "yes, via induction on subwords because of the weakly collapsing property", but I thought I had a counterexample a while ago so I was wrong at least once! which is one way to get from CR​(u⋄v)=R(CR​(u)⋄CR​(v)) to CR​(u⋄v)=CR​(CR​(u)⋄CR​(v)) and get a model of E.

Does that make sense?

I think this section could use a few sentences to clarify the storyline.

You're correct on all points! I did think the thing I described was indeed a model, but it's not in general, so I'll make a PR at least fixing that tomorrow.

6.7 is enough for idempotency, at least in the sense that if R is collapsing then C_R is idempotent, that's proven in Confluence.lean. The collapsing condition is quite strong. It's also quite useful in magmas, I think, since there's only one function symbol/operation.

I proved 6.8 in Lean, because I don't trust my paper proofs anymore (if I ever did). I do actually think this is sufficient for being a model. At any rate one can always reconstruct such a model from the matching invariant one way or another.

I'll prove it tomorrow as well if I have time, otherwise I'll just delete the offending sentence and leave it at that, unless there's an objection.

@Cody Roux : thanks!

While I'm browsing metatheorems.tex, we say

(1) We work in the free group $\Magma_X$ on two generators $X = \{\x,\y\}$. Free group, or free magma?

(2) We have two references to M_X which should probably be Magma_X.

I think I'm slowly running out of typos.. :upside_down:
You're a hero!

Perhaps it is time for an update from the various people involved in writing the paper to report on how they are progressing? I think it would be good to wrap things up while we still have reasonably fresh memories of the project.
I’ll wrap up in the next 36 hours
I am almost done in any case. Just need to go over the notes and check if I covered all the points and add them.
Apologies for the delay, it shall be done soon.
Finally fixed the typos caught by @Douglas McNeil , things should be done on my side AFAIK.

About our work on various types of spectra of equations, I will write (hopefully next week) something about the full spectrum problem (for the paper). Possibly also something for the blueprint, but I am not sure what will make sense to write there.

The full discussion of counting magmas etc would be better placed in a separate publication I would say, as it is only loosely connected to the implication graph. (However, we did make heavy use of the implication graph to know the finite equivalence classes, and to directly know that some equations were gaseous as soon as stronger equations were shown to be.) Does that make sense?
I think it could easily be an appendix of the paper or even a section

The paper is already somewhat long and sprawling, and is only intended to be a sampler of the results we have rather than a comprehensive list. So we can mention this spinoff and say that details will appear elsewhere (either in the blueprint, or in some completely separate document).

The blueprint can be held to much more relaxed standards of writing than the paper which is to be submitted to a research journal, in particular a minimally organized and only partially complete discussion is I think fine there, especially given that it can always be updated later (one can insert "TODO"s etc. as needed if one wishes to emphasize the incomplete nature).

Reading the conclusion section of the paper, I notice that E5093 is misquoted here (and in Appendix A), it should be x = y ◇ (y ◇ (y ◇ (x ◇ (z ◇ y)))) or in TeX code \x \formaleq \y \op (\y \op (\y \op (\x \op (\z \op \y)))). The currently quoted equation is E11232 x = y ◇ ((y ◇ (y ◇ x)) ◇ (z ◇ y)). I don't have access to Kisielewicz' paper https://doi.org/10.1007/s000120050057 to see if he also discusses that equation. If anyone has access I'd be interested, if only to record all equation numbers in the commentary.

Another confusion I have about the conclusion is the usage of "surjunctive" for the property that « maps from M to itself that are surjective are necessarily injective ». Firstly, up to axiom of choice subtleties, this property is equivalent to finiteness. It only stops being so if we restrict to maps that are built from the magma operation somehow. This may be related to the usual definition of surjunctivity for groups, which appears to involve cellular automata, but I don't understand enough to fix this. (Incidentally it is possible that the implications 3342⇒3522 and 3342⇒4118 may have surjunctive counterexamples despite holding for all finite magmas, since we use stronger properties than just surjectivity⇔injectivity.)

Thanks! On looking at the original paper of Kisielewicz it looks like this was a typo and 5093 should be used instead:

image.png

I've fixed the manuscript accordingly. As for surjunctivity, the intention is to restrict attention to definable maps as you say; I've modified the wording to make this clearer.
Any further updates from section writers? Hopefully we are close to the finish line...
I’ll have time to do my final pass tomorrow
Pushed many edits today. A little bit remains.
I am briefl writing about the blueprint. But isn’t the standard blueprint already described in detail in other ITP papers?

I don’t want to say anything beyond “we use the blueprint to tool to organise and track our effort. Unlike other projects, this project did not have a small number of specific top level goals but ca. 22 million goals of a similar sort, which were resolved in wildly different ways. Thus unlike projects where we start with a blueprint to guide our progress, we found ourselves guided by ATP explorations. The blueprint followed these discoveries and formalisation came afterwards, or in tandem”
We can quote an example here maybe

Also, do we have a guideline for citing the daily log? Currently I am citing the repository and mentioning the daily log entry in the optional argument . Adding a separation citation bibtex entry for the logs feels like overcitation

I have removed references to the log. A first draft is ready for review (https://github.com/teorth/equational_theories/pull/1038). I could merge this PR and then subsequent PRs could edit this section
I think the engineering issues which are solved by duality and transitive closure should be mentioned in the metatheory section to avoid redundancy

I think this level of mention of the blueprint is fine - it is a component of the project, but not a central one like it is in formalization projects, still it is worth making the point that blueprinting can be useful as a secondary tool.

I think the github repository is a good enough reference for all material hosted there (blueprint, log, etc.), and that specific URLs are not necessary.

Overall looks good! A lot of things stated that may be "obvious" to participants inside the project, but would be valuable information for people interested in starting a collaborative project from no starting experience. I added some mostly grammatical comments.
I think I have responded to almost all of the review comments. If there are no further review comments, I will merge this PR tonight so the content appears on the main paper pdf
We can still make changes in subsequent PRs
There were no comments. I have merged. This also saves any further merge conflicts. In sometime the new version of the paper should show up on the webpage. Feedback is definitely welcome.

Some useful facts.
A finite algebra A is:

1) primal if for every n and every function f : A^n --> A there is a term t(x1,...,xn) that expresses f .
This is a well-known property of the 2-element Boolean algebra.

2) idemprimal if for every n and every idempotent function f : A^n --> A there is a term t(x1,...,xn) that expresses f .
f is idempotent means f(a,...,a) = a for all a in A.

3) quasiprimal if the (discriminator) function f : A^3 --> A defined by
f(a,b,c) = c if a =b, and f(a,b,c) = a if a \neq b
is expressed by some (discriminator) term t(x,y,z).
(Clearly such an f is idempotent, so idemprimal implies quasiprimal.)

For a historical note, quasiprimal algebras played a key role in the difficult question of determining which varieties V generated by finitely many finite algebras have a decidable first-order theory. (The equational theory of V is obviously decidable, since an equation E holds on all members of V iff it holds on the finitely many finite generators.)

There are simple tests to determine if a quasiprimal A is idemprimal or primal, namely
1) A is idemprimal iff it is rigid (the only automorphism is the identity map on A) and any subalgebra of A that is not A is trivial (only one element);
2) A is primal iff it is idemprimal and its only subalgebra is A.

The only 2-element quasiprimal magma is the Boolean algebra (with the Sheffer stroke), and it is primal.

However one can distinguish quasiprimal from idemprimal from primal with 3-element magmas. (This was pointed out to me by Marcel Jackson of La Trobe University in Australia.)

I am a little concerned about the convention on page 3 for the use of the symbol ⊢\vdash⊢ as it is contrary to what Sanka and I adopted for our book of 1981. So I took the risky step of asking ChatGPT about the meaning of "entailment" and was amazed to see that I completely agreed with it. As food for thought I pass the chat on to you:

Chat with ChatGPT

What symbol is used to express one equation entails another equation?

In logic and mathematics, the symbol used to express that one equation entails another depends on the context—syntactic or semantic. Here’s the breakdown:

1. Semantic entailment (meaning-based):

Symbol: ⊨\models⊨
Usage:

E1⊨E2E_1 \models E_2E1​⊨E2​ means that in every interpretation (or structure) in which the equation E1E_1E1​ holds, the equation
E2E_2E2​ also holds.

Read as:
* “E1E_1E1​ semantically entails E2E_2E2​”

  • or “E2E_2E2​ is a semantic consequence of E1E_1E1​”

  • or “whenever E1E_1E1​ is true, E2E_2E2​ is true.”

Example:

x=y⊨x+z=y+zx = y \models x + z = y + zx=y⊨x+z=y+z

In every algebraic structure where x=yx = yx=y is true, so is x+z=y+zx + z = y + zx+z=y+z.

2. Syntactic entailment (provability in a deductive system):

Symbol: ⊢\vdash⊢
Usage:
E1⊢E2E_1 \vdash E_2E1​⊢E2​
means that E2E_2E2​ can be derived from E1E_1E1​ using a system of inference rules.
Read as:
* “E1E_1E1​ proves E2E_2E2​”

  • “E2E_2E2​ is derivable from E1E_1E1​”

  • “E2E_2E2​ follows from E1E_1E1​ by formal proof.”

[Table for 3. Summary of Usage not copied here.]

If you’re working in universal algebra or equational logic, the semantic entailment ⊨\models⊨ is usually the appropriate symbol to express that one equation entails another (i.e. holds in all algebras where the first holds).
Fair enough, I've changed the entailment symbol and the footnote.

Perhaps an example from ring theory will put the two notions of entailment, namely ⊢\vdash⊢ and ⊨\models⊨, in sharper relief.

Using ⊢\vdash⊢ vs using ⊨\models⊨

Let RngAx be a collection of axioms for rings.
In Herstein's book Topics in Algebra one finds the following three exercises over a few dozen pages:

RngAx with x2=xx^2=xx2=x implies xy=yxxy=yxxy=yx
RngAx with x3=xx^3=xx3=x implies xy=yxxy=yxxy=yx
RngAx with x4=xx^4=xx4=x implies xy=yxxy=yxxy=yx

Students are expected to solve each of these by the simple means of manipulating equations, like obtaining (x+y)2=x+y(x+y)^2 = x+y(x+y)2=x+y in the first case, and then expanding the left hand size, etc. The first exercise is rather easy, the second is more demanding, and Herstein told me that he had more correspondence on the third than any other exercise in his book. And many a mathematician has played with higher values of nnn, trying to prove by such elementary means that

RngAx with xn=xx^n=xxn=x implies xy=yxxy=yxxy=yx.

Here the value of nnn is fixed for each proof. A proof by such means would be an example of showing that

RngAx , xn=x⊢xy=yxx^n=x \vdash xy=yxxn=x⊢xy=yx.

One has a precisely described deduction system, say Birkhoff's equational logic, with precisely described options for generating new equations. No appeal is made to look at the structure of rings. It has the flavor of combinatorics.

In 1945 Jacobson gave a single proof that for all n≥2n \ge 2n≥2 one has
RngAx with xn=xx^n=xxn=x implies xy=yxxy=yxxy=yx
by examining the impact on a ring R of requiring that it satisfy
xn=xx^n=xxn=x. One is really bringing set theory into play looking at ideals and homomorphisms with the option to bring in any set constructions that seem useful. For this kind of proof we write

RngAx , xn=x⊨xy=yxx^n=x \models xy=yxxn=x⊨xy=yx.

It is common to view the world of proofs found by computers as belonging to the syntactic side (⊢\vdash⊢), whereas invoking models, often infinite, belongs to the semantic side (⊨\models⊨) on the grounds that a computer cannot verify an assertion by trying infinitely many or infinitely large models.

These distinctions, syntactic vs semantic, begin to blur as ATP systems become capable of inventing and using set-theoretic constructions and reasoning in the quest for a proof. But now I am getting into philosophical questions about the future of mathematics, so time to stop.

Data and examples on 3-element magmas.

In collaboration with Marcel Jackson we have the following:

1) The number of primals is 629.

2) The number of idemprimals that are not primal is 777.

3) The number of quasiprimals that are not idemprimal is 79.

100 020 000 is primal.

001 020 102 is idemprimal, not primal.

001 021 211 is quasiprimal, not idemprimal.

This information was independently extracted by both of us from the B&B catalog of 3-element magmas by hand following Marcel's discovery that one could separate the notions of primal, idemprimal and quasiprimal by such magmas.

The claim that for all n>= 2, (for all x, x^n=x => R is commutative) must have some content, because it implies the delicate (but standard) result that a finite division ring is a field (and hence that the Brauer group of a finite field is trivial). Apparently Jacobson proved an even stronger result: if for all x in a ring, there exists some natural n(x)>=2 such that x^(n(x))=x, then R is commutative.

I now remember thinking some months ago when writing portions of the paper that due to the Birkhoff completeness theorem, this particular distinction wasn't an issue for magmas and one could use $\vdash$ and $\models$ interchangeably. But we also consider the analogue $\models_{\mathrm{fin}}$ of semantic entailment for finite magmas, and in this case we don't have a complete syntactic calculus (or at least, we have not proposed one - we have some additional axioms like surjunctivity, but it is unlikely that they are complete), so the distinction is certainly relevant here.
we prove almost all positive implications syntactically right?

@Kevin Buzzard Thanks for pointing out that one certainly needs
n≥2n\ge2n≥2, and that the result "for all n≥2n\ge2n≥2" is certainly much stronger than the particular cases n=2n=2n=2, etc. I know some mathematicians have tried to give an algorithm which for each n≥2n\ge2n≥2 shows how to write down an elementary (equational logic) proof that xy=yxxy=yxxy=yx, where we are justified in using ⊢\vdash⊢, but I do not know if such an algorithm has appeared anywhere.

A set theorist could point out that Jacobson's strong result proving that xn(x)=xx^{n(x)} = xxn(x)=x implies commutativity can be written up as a single (formal) sentence φ\varphiφ in the language of ZFC, and thus one would write ZFC ⊢φ\vdash \varphi⊢φ, or simply ⊢φ\vdash \varphi⊢φ if the context is one of working with formal proofs in ZFC. The distinction between ⊢\vdash⊢ and ⊨\models⊨ evidently depends on whether or not one is looking at a proof in the context of a formal system (like ZFC, or Birkhoff's equational logic), or in the context of an informal system (like naive set theory). And probably one would write ZFC ⊨φ\models \varphi⊨φ if one is claiming that every model of ZFC satisfies φ\varphiφ in the context of naive set theory. The context of a formal mathematical system would evidently be the metamathematics for that system.

In 1968, when the Hungarian logician Kalmar was visiting UWaterloo, he said (as best I can remember) that one could have a hierarchy of contexts, each one being a metasystem for the previous level. This is all great material for the philosophy of mathematics, but a rather rich diet for my tastes. (Kalmar, by the way, was the young mathematician who fixed a problem with Landau's course notes on the foundations of mathematics where Landau was falsely claiming to use the axiom of choice to define the usual operations on the natural numbers. This inspired Landau to publish his famous Grundlagen der Analysis.)

By the way, Herstein comments towards the end of his book that the strongest form of Jacobson's result requires the Axiom of Choice, a digression that he declines to take in his book. I do not know the status of that claim today.

I'm a little confused so I'll just write down what I think I understand and people can correct me:

  1. Birkhoff's theorem does hold for equational logic: if an equation is entailed by others, then there is a syntactic proof. And indeed, if we know that the entailment holds (and the set of assumed equations is finite), there is an algorithm to find it: just enumerate all the proofs. It is cool that Vampire does actually find them though.
  2. It sounds like the theorem @Kevin Buzzard alluded to is: fix a natural number n≥2n \geq 2n≥2. Then, if RRR is the first order theory of rings, then R∪∀x,xn=x⊨∀xy,xy=yxR\cup \forall x, x^n = x\models \forall x y, x y = y xR∪∀x,xn=x⊨∀xy,xy=yx. If that is the case, then the completeness theorem for first order logic applies, and we can replace ⊨\models⊨ with ⊢\vdash⊢. I certainly know how to do the proof for n=2n=2n=2, but maybe it gets harder for larger nnn. Again, one can find some trivial algorithm to do this, by just enumerating proofs.
  3. The statement ∀x∃n≥2,xn=x\forall x\exists n\geq 2, x^n = x∀x∃n≥2,xn=x is not a statement in the first order theory of rings, so the same does not apply.

Terence Tao ha dicho:

due to the Birkhoff completeness theorem, this particular distinction wasn't an issue for magmas and one could use $\vdash$ and $\models$ interchangeably.

Yup, and this is true more in general in the setting of (first-order) model theory thanks to Gödel's _completeness_ theorem (symbolic provability amounts to semantic truth). This is relevant to us, since we don't restrict to universal algebra -we often add other first-order conditions like injectivity of some map, and we are always negating some sentence.

Terence Tao ha dicho:

But we also consider the analogue $\models_{\mathrm{fin}}$ of semantic entailment for finite magmas, and in this case we don't have a complete syntactic calculus (or at least, we have not proposed one

We cannot give a syntactic calculus for the finite setting, at least not within first-order logic: by the upward Löwenheim-Skolem theorem (a straightforward corollary of the compactness theorem), if a first-order theory has arbitrarily large finite models, then it has infinite models.

For a while I tried to find some higher-order characterization of finite cardinality that we could effectively use in Vampire (which is able of managing higher-order), but I didn't succeed, in part because the HO logic in Vampire doesn't seem to be well documented anywhere. I think this tool, if at hand, would be quite useful, particularly for 677 anti 255.

As regards the three items of @Cody Roux:

  1. ...there is an algorithm to find it: just enumerate all the proofs.

Indeed that fits the meaning of algorithm, but those trying to find an algorithm were looking for a direct method with "no unnecessary steps", all steps focused on how to write down the formal proof. It seems they also wanted one where the computational complexity is not too great so one can find the proof by hand for small nnn.

  1. ...but maybe it gets harder for larger nnn.

Indeed it gets harder for nnn increasing from 2 to 4.

  1. ...is not a statement in the first order theory of rings, so the same does not apply.

Agreed! One could translate an informal proof of such a statement into a formal proof in first-order logic, in ZFC, so perhaps Jacobson's theorem can be proved by an ATP someday.

page 46: "how many finite magmas exist of each size in the spectrum."

W. Taylor — “The fine spectrum of a variety.” Algebra Universalis 5 (1975), 263–303.

and there are the closely related

Joel Berman & Paweł M. Idziak — Generative Complexity in Algebra. Memoirs of the AMS, 2005.

Kamilla Kátai-Urbán, András Pongrácz & Csaba Szabó — “The fine- and generative spectra of varieties of monounary algebras.” Algebra Universalis (2019).

M. Bilski — “Generative complexity in semigroup varieties.” Journal of Algebra (2001).
— Studies generative complexity in semigroup varieties; cites Taylor on fine spectrum and explores related enumeration problems.

The order of a magma does not seem to be defined in the paper. It first appears on page 8

order equal to a perfect square n2n^2n2;

The order of a finite magma is implicitly defined on page 21:

A finite magma M{\mathcal M}M of order nnn can be labeled by the carrier {1,...,n}\{1, . . . , n\}{1,...,n}

The phrase "can be labeled by" is more precisely captured by "can be assumed to have" and then add "by replacing M{\mathcal M}M by an isomorphic copy if necessary".

I usually prefer the carrier {1,...,n}\{1, . . . , n\}{1,...,n} to {0,...,n−1}\{0, . . . , n-1\}{0,...,n−1}, but there are set-theoretic reasons for choosing the latter. Namely for JJJ a non-empty set one usually defines MJ{\mathcal M}^JMJ to be the magma with carrier MJM^JMJ, being the set of functions from JJJ to MMM. Then for f,g∈MJf,g \in M^Jf,g∈MJ one has f=gf=gf=g iff for all j∈Jj\in Jj∈J, f(j)=g(j)f(j) = g(j)f(j)=g(j), and f⋄gf\diamond gf⋄g is defined by (f⋄g)(j):=f(j)⋄g(j)(f\diamond g)(j) := f(j) \diamond g(j)(f⋄g)(j):=f(j)⋄g(j). But then to carry this over to Mn{\mathcal M}^nMn for nnn a positive integer set-theorists use the fact that in set-theory one has n={0,…,n−1}n = \{0,\ldots,n-1\}n={0,…,n−1}.

Yes, I confirm I'm working on it! :smile: I was redoing some experiments, and trying to synthesize what I can really say. About comparing ATPs properly I only have two small (but informative) comparisons between Vampire and Prover9, I have more info about tweaking Prover9/Mace4, comparisons between sets of parameters with specific examples. Also some basic comments on semiguidance and such, how times are improved adding other constraints, and how we integrated the ATPs with SAGE. In addition, during the project I experimented with other interesting Prover9 features like semantic guidance and addition of hints, but they didn't work for me and I don't think it is useful to say so (perhaps it was just me not doing things well enough). On the other hand, I would like to mention the isofilter bug we found, and some other basic comments regarding the GUI versus the terminal (see below), which can be useful for unaware new users (but I'm a bit hesitant about their real value for our paper, perhaps you can give your opinion about this).

I have also run into some problems (for example for logistic reasons I had to use 3 different combinations of hardware/software, that I need to compare now), the biggest one being the following: the GUI uses a previous version of Prover9/Mace4 (the latest one can only be used via terminal), but in my experience it seemed to be sometimes faster than the latest one! This I have confirmed these days with a dramatic example: the longest Prover9 proof, found in the HN subproject (which originally needed several computation hours to be found), can be found in 8 minutes with the GUI with max_weight 300 and sos_limit 200. In startling contrast, with the same parameters, the latest version fails to find a proof, exhausting the search after several hours (9h in a slightly slower machine). Idk if this is due to some default parameters not being actually the same in the two versions (shouldn't be the case if I have read the manual and the GUI options correctly, which I've done carefully these days), or to an important behaviour change in the latest version with respect to the GUI one; in any case, that the behaviour is quite different is evidenced by the clauses statistics found in the output files, which differ significantly between both versions.

I'd really like to be able to warn about this problem by identifying its cause (a priori, from the statistics differences one should be able to infer where the problem lies), but I fear it would imply learning the inner workings of some very specific inference processes of Prover9 (I tried to reach McCune before realizing that he sadly died in 2011... Also asked @Zoltan A. Kocsis (Z.A.K.) in case he knows how to identify the problem, but I think he hasn't read me yet).

All in all, I think that in the end I will be happy adding several small paragraphs to the paper, so not much information, but (hopefully) interesting nonetheless.

First, it was unclear to me why there is a "(weakly)" in the first bullet point. Just call it "collapsing" unless there is a good reason to call it "weakly collapsing", in which case the parentheses should be removed and the word "weakly" should be italicized. It might make sense to change "sub-word" -> "(not-necessarily proper) sub-word" in any case.

Second, in the second bullet point, the notation \theta(w)=w\theta is introduced. In my experience, it is a very bad idea to introduce notation that rearranges the order of symbols. This is often a sign of trying to hide important information in the notation, and often leads to very ugly (and hard to follow) equations. Thus, I recommend using \theta(w)=\theta w.

In other words, dropping the parentheses is fine. Reversing the order is not.

Third, in the third bullet point, again is there a reason for the qualifier "weak"? If not, it should be dropped.

Fourth, the numbered equations (10)-(14) should not be numbered.

Now, we want to apply the fact that R is a canonizer. To do that we need to know that $(C_R\theta)a \diamond (C_R\theta)b$ is some substitution applied to $l$. Note that $a$ and $b$ are proper sub-words of $l$, so if they are not variables then the fact that $R$ is non-overlapping comes into play. But if they are variables, then something else occurs.

As best as I can guess, we are now doing another induction, to claim that $C_R\circ \theta$ is a substitution on proper subwords of $\ell$. Anyway, even after that, does this mean that $C_R\circ \theta$ is a substitution on $r$? Thus, the last two equalities are very hard for me to see.

I finished reading through the paper, which was very educational! Here are the rest of my (all minor) suggestions:

p. 24, paragraph preceding Example 5.2. In two places, replace \subset with \subseteq.

p. 36, Definition 6.7, second bullet point. Replace \varphi with \varphi_{\theta} in one place.

p. 36, Definition 6.7, fourth bullet point. Replace R(w\theta) with R(\varphi_{\theta}w) in one place.

p. 36, Theorem 6.9. When observing that r is a sub-word of l, it might be helpful to add "since R is weakly collapsing and a weak canonizer".

Also, technically speaking, there is nothing in the definitions to prevent R from being the trivial map and from l=r. So we don't know that r is a proper sub-word. This can be easily handled a number of ways. For instance, we could break into cases, and handle the trivial case l=r separately. Or a nontriviality hypothesis could be added somewhere. Or the implicit assumption l\neq r could be added to a definition somewhere. I personally prefer the first option; just handle the trivial case separately.

p. 37, phrase "from the above equality". Is this the equality in Definition 6.6(2), or some other equality? This should probably be specified.

p. 38, in one place \tilde{w} \to_E \tilde{w} appears, but the first term should have a dash on it.

p. 41. There is a big space after "i.e." (in the Equational Reasoning" paragraph) probably from a missing backslash after the period.

p. 50. Should "in the table below" be changed to "in Table 3" (especially since Table 2 is also below, currently?)

p. 56. In question (2), the phrase "no finite models" should probably be "no nontrivial finite models"

Also, I'd be a bit surprised if question (4) is open.

p. 57. In the string of inequalities

∗<∗⋄∗<∗⋄(∗⋄∗)<(∗⋄∗)⋄∗\ast < \ast\diamond \ast < \ast\diamond (\ast\diamond \ast) < (\ast\diamond \ast)\diamond \ast∗<∗⋄∗<∗⋄(∗⋄∗)<(∗⋄∗)⋄∗

if we add

<∗⋄(∗⋄(∗⋄∗))<∗⋄((∗⋄∗)⋄∗)<⋯< \ast \diamond (\ast \diamond (\ast\diamond\ast)) < \ast \diamond ((\ast\diamond \ast)\diamond \ast)<\cdots<∗⋄(∗⋄(∗⋄∗))<∗⋄((∗⋄∗)⋄∗)<⋯

this demonstrates the need for the third bullet point. If we include that last \cdots, the words "for instance" at the start of the sentence can be removed.

The open question 5 on page 56 has an easy answer (and perhaps other easy answers that could be discovered using the equation explorer). The implication E2 -> E4 is irreducible. The proof is very easy. First, note that E4 implies any law of the form l=r where the left-most variable of l matches the left-most variable of r. On the other hand, E4 in conjunction with any law not of that form yields E2.

By the way, in the commentary in the equation explorer on E3, the word "exactly" should be removed.
Thanks, I have changed the open question to give this example and ask for more irreducible implications, and updated the commentary as well.

For what it's worth, there are infinitely many examples of irreducible implications: E2⊨E895, E2⊨E26302, E2⊨E5⊨E13, etc.

Boring details

  • E2⊨E895 (Boolean group law): assume E⊨E895 and count modulo 2 the number of times each variable appears. If each one appears an even number of times then E⇔E895. Otherwise E⇔E2 since any model of E is a Boolean group, in which E reduces to x=0.

  • https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/BFb0013055 gives a single-law EnE_nEn​ characterizing abelian groups of any given odd exponent nnn. For any prime ppp the implication En⊨EnpE_n\models E_{np}En​⊨Enp​ is irreducible. Consider an intermediate law E. In any given model of E (which is necessarily an abelian group of exponent npnpnp), E reduces to a linear equation k1x+k2y+⋯=0k_1 x+k_2 y+\dots=0k1​x+k2​y+⋯=0 with ki∈[0,np)k_i\in[0,np)ki​∈[0,np), so that the abelian group has exponent gcd⁡(k1,k2,… )\operatorname{gcd}(k_1,k_2,\dots)gcd(k1​,k2​,…). It must hold in any abelian group of exponent nnn, so kik_iki​ are multiples of nnn and the gcd is either nnn or npnpnp.

  • E2⊨E26302 (natural central groupoid law) is irreducible for a similar reason to E2⊨E895: natural central groupoids are characterized by the set of idempotents and any further equation either holds in any natural central groupoid or forces the set to be trivial.

  • The implication E5⊨E13 is irreducible. Actually, we have the stronger property that E2⊨E13 is next-to-irreducible in the sense that any law E with E2⊨E⊨E13 must be equivalent to E2, E5, or E13. Indeed, E13 states that x◇y=S(y) with S(S(y))=y. Evaluating both sides of E using these identities gives one of x=y, x=S(y), x=x, or x=S(x), in which cases E is equivalent to E2, E2, E13, and E5, respectively. Of course the same properties hold with E13 replaced by E62 (stating that x◇y=S(y) with S a bijection of order 3) or similar equations involving S of prime order. And there are whole families of implications that are next-to-next-to-irreducible, etc.

I am talking about the technical contributions of the paper as whole, not that of individual contributions. I have a sample for the initial text below (composed in a bus on a phone).

The Equational Theories project was a mathematical project aimed at resolving the relationships between 4694 equations of 2, 3, or 4 variables. Additionally it was an academic experiment in organising large scale mathematical collaborations using interactive and automated theorem provers. In this paper, we report on our processes and the results of this project. Concretely,

  1. We managed to resolve all 22 x 10^6 pairs of equations.
  2. Additionally we managed to resolve all but one pairs of equations when only finite models are allowed for refuting an implication.
  3. We also developed a suite of techniques for resolving such implications using a combination of heuristics and automated theorem provers and verified the results in lean
  4. We developed a collection of tools and techniques to organise and visualise the project and track its progress, which we believe will serve as a useful template for such projects in the future.

So this is a lesson learned: we should have sorted out how we were going to handle this earlier. Next time. :upside_down: But let me sketch an argument that we're okay submitting tomorrow.

The arXiv policy is that the submitting author agrees

  • I am completing this Agreement on behalf of and binding upon all author(s).
  • I have full authority to enter into and make this Agreement and to grant the rights contained in this Agreement. If the Work was created by multiple authors, I affirm that my co-author(s) have consented to the submission of the Work to arXiv under the Agreement terms with me acting on my co-author(s)’ behalf.

In large, more hierarchical, collaborations in astronomy, in practice the leader of each subteam typically consents on behalf of everyone they're overseeing. Sometimes paperwork goes out to everyone to positively assent and people get chased down on holidays, etc. In our group that won't work, not least of which is that some of us answer to no one. :sunglasses: The conventions are more sophisticated than you might assume, though, everyone knows that different people did different parts and coauthor G isn't held responsible for mistakes in team R's section.

In our case, everything is public, and every named author (along with everyone else on the planet!) has had an opportunity to follow the development of the paper at whatever frequency they liked. The action of contributing your name to the paper (assuming we added no one without direction) given our public Zulip+github setup is a presumptive consent that you're okay with the expected forward movement of the process, given that at any moment you have the opportunity to opt out.

I do think we should arrange a more formal signoff before submission to a journal proper, given that our submitting author is on the hook for the agreement, but I'd be okay with @-ing all submitters ASAP giving them a veto period for now. We then require one final positive assent from everyone before journal submission, which we can start as early as possible (maybe following Shreyas' thread idea) to give us the largest window to connect with our less online members.

For what it is worth, I tasked Claude Opus with peer reviewing the paper in its current form. I'll share the resulting report here. Take the content with the usual LLM-sized grain of salt, but also do feel free to act on this if anything stands out as important to you.

Peer Review Report: Equational Theories Project Paper

Issues Ranked by Severity

HIGH SEVERITY (Correctness Issues)

1. Incorrect equation in ml.tex (line 3)

- Issue: The law $\Eq{1659}$ is stated as "$\x \op ((\y \op \y) \op \z) \formaleq \x \op y$" but the correct form per numbering.tex is "$\x \formaleq (\x \op \y) \op ((\y \op \y) \op \z)$"
- Note: The y at the end is also missing the backslash (\y)
- Location: paper/ml.tex:3

2. Missing \times M in variety definition (constructions.tex:52)

- Issue: The variety for the idempotent law is written as "$ (a,b) \in M: a+b=1 $" but should be "$ (a,b) \in M \times M: a+b=1 $" for consistency with the preceding examples
- Location: paper/constructions.tex:52

3. Inconsistent variable notation in Examples (constructions.tex:49, 56, 58)

- Issue: Uses x, y, z instead of \x, \y, \z which are used consistently elsewhere in the paper. This creates visual inconsistency.
- Location: paper/constructions.tex:49, 56, 58

MEDIUM SEVERITY (Inconsistencies/Uncertainties)

4. Inconsistent counts: "820 or 822" vs "820"

- Issue: intro.tex states "either $820$ or $822$" pairs while austin.tex says definitively "$820$ new implications". Similarly for the anti-implications: intro.tex says "$13854535$ or $13854537$"
- Impact: This uncertainty about final counts undermines confidence in completeness
- Location: paper/intro.tex:134, 144 vs paper/austin.tex:5

5. Missing \Cref for subsection reference (constructions.tex:305)

- Issue: Uses \ref{greedy-sec} instead of \Cref{greedy-sec} which is used consistently elsewhere
- Location: paper/constructions.tex:305

6. Inconsistent appendix references (higman.tex:28)

- Issue: Uses "Appendix \ref{numbering-app}" while intro.tex uses \Cref{numbering-app} consistently
- Location: paper/higman.tex:28

LOW SEVERITY (Bibliography/Minor Issues)

7. Duplicate bibliography entry for Sheffer

- Issue: Both @article{sheffer,...} (line 137) and @article{sheffer1913set,...} (line 219) reference the same 1913 Sheffer paper. Only sheffer appears to be cited.
- Location: paper/references.bib:137, 219

8. Missing year in bibliography entry

- Issue: The githubGitHubPatrickMassotleanblueprint entry has year = {}, (empty)
- Location: paper/references.bib:958

9. Unusual/non-standard citation key naming

- Issue: githubGitHubPatrickMassotleanblueprint and GitHubGitHubPatrickMassotleanblueprint appear to be the same but are cited differently in project.tex (uses the capitalized version which doesn't match the bib entry exactly—though

BibTeX is case-insensitive, this is confusing)

- Location: paper/references.bib:954, paper/project.tex:20

SUGGESTIONS (Not Errors)

10. Future dates in paper

- The paper references dates like "July 30, 2025" (project.tex:60 figure caption) and "22-09-2025" (references.bib). If this paper is to be published before these dates, consider whether these should be updated.

11. Equations used but not defined in numbering.tex appendix

- Several equations are referenced via \Eq{n} notation (e.g., $\Eq{14}$, $\Eq{492}$, $\Eq{1090}$, $\Eq{1482}$, $\Eq{1523}$, $\Eq{1682}$ in spectrum.tex) that are not listed in the appendix's equation table. While the \Eq{} macro just

renders as "En", having these in the appendix would aid readers.
12. Higman-Neumann section not formalized

- The section explicitly states the results "have not been formalized in Lean yet" (higman.tex:54). This is appropriate disclosure but worth noting as a limitation.

Summary

The paper is generally well-written with clear mathematical exposition. The most significant issues are:

1. The incorrect equation form for $\Eq{1659}$ in the ML section
2. The uncertainty in final counts (820 vs 822, etc.)
3. Minor typographical inconsistencies in variable notation

These should be addressed before publication. The bibliography issues are minor cleanup items.

For the fourth point (on not(E854⊨E4) and not(E854⊨E10)) we could mention that the E854⊨E4 counterexample is a magma of size 2 and the E854⊨E10 counterexample is a magma of size 11 (minimal, I just checked, and there are many such magmas).

For the fifth point about constant laws, come on, this is abusive pedantry, the laws are equivalent.
